title: P06-1018

sentences.text: This paper proposes a generic mathematical formalism for the combination of various structures : strings , trees , dags , graphs , and products of them .
The polarization of the objects of the elementary structures controls the saturation of the final structure .
This formalism is both elementary and powerful enough to strongly simulate many grammar formalisms , such as rewriting systems , dependency grammars , TAG , HPSG and LFG .

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a generic mathematical formalism designed to combine various structures, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, while controlling the saturation of the final structure through the polarization of elementary objects.

Entity-a_generic_mathematical_formalism.label: a generic mathematical formalism
Entity-a_generic_mathematical_formalism.description: A generic mathematical formalism that facilitates the combination of various data structures, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, while controlling the saturation of the final structure through the polarization of elementary objects.

Entity-generic_mathematical_formalism.label: generic mathematical formalism
Entity-generic_mathematical_formalism.description: The term 'generic mathematical formalism' refers to a versatile mathematical framework designed to integrate and manipulate various structural forms, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and other graph types, while allowing for the control of structural properties through polarization, thereby enabling the simulation of multiple grammar formalisms.

Entity-this_formalism.label: This formalism
Entity-this_formalism.description: This formalism refers to a generic mathematical framework proposed in the paper for combining various structures like strings, trees, dags, and graphs, which is capable of simulating multiple grammar formalisms.

Entity-the_polarization_of_the_object_of.label: the polarization of the objects of the elementary structures
aliases: the polarization of the objects of the elementary structures
Entity-the_polarization_of_the_object_of.description: The polarization of the objects of the elementary structures refers to a mathematical concept that governs how different foundational structures, such as strings and graphs, interact and combine to determine the completeness or saturation of a resulting composite structure in formal grammar systems.

mentions.local_name: the polarization of the objects of the elementary structures

Entity-elementary_structure.label: elementary structures
Entity-elementary_structure.description: Elementary structures refer to fundamental components or configurations, such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, that are manipulated within a mathematical formalism to control the properties and saturation of more complex structures in the context of grammar formalisms.

Entity-formalism.label: formalism
Entity-formalism.description: The term 'formalism' refers to a generic mathematical framework proposed in the paper for combining various structures, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and other graph types, which is capable of simulating multiple grammar formalisms.

Entity-structure.label: structures
Entity-structure.description: The term 'structures' refers to various mathematical objects such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, which can be combined using a proposed formalism to simulate different grammar formalisms.

Entity-various_structure.label: various structures
Entity-various_structure.description: The term 'various structures' refers to a collection of mathematical entities including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), graphs, and their combinations, which are utilized in a proposed formalism for simulating different grammar formalisms.

Entity-graph.label: graphs
Entity-graph.description: In this paper, 'graphs' refer to mathematical objects that are part of a generic formalism for combining various structures, including strings, trees, and directed acyclic graphs (dags), to model complex relationships and interactions in formal systems.

Entity-polarization.label: polarization
Entity-polarization.description: In this context, 'polarization' refers to a mathematical property that influences how the objects of elementary structures interact and combine, ultimately affecting the saturation of the resulting complex structure in the proposed formalism.

Entity-the_saturation_of_the_final_struc.label: the saturation of the final structure
aliases: the saturation of the final structure
Entity-the_saturation_of_the_final_struc.description: The saturation of the final structure refers to the degree to which the combined mathematical structures, influenced by the polarization of their elementary components, achieve a complete and cohesive form in the proposed formalism.

mentions.local_name: the saturation of the final structure

Entity-string.label: strings
Entity-string.description: In this paper, 'strings' refer to sequences of characters or symbols that serve as fundamental data structures in the proposed mathematical formalism for combining various structures, including trees, dags, and graphs.

Entity-tree.label: trees
Entity-tree.description: In this paper, 'trees' refer to a type of mathematical object and data structure used in the proposed formalism for combining various structures, which includes strings, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs.

Entity-product.label: products
Entity-product.description: In this paper, 'products' refers to the mathematical constructs resulting from the combination of various structures such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs within a proposed formalism.

Entity-final_structure.label: final structure
Entity-final_structure.description: The 'final structure' refers to the resulting configuration of combined elementary structures, influenced by their polarization and saturation, as defined within a generic mathematical formalism for various structural types.

Entity-saturation.label: saturation
Entity-saturation.description: In this context, 'saturation' refers to a mathematical property that describes the extent to which the final structure, formed by combining various elementary structures, is filled or completed based on the polarization of those structures.

Entity-object.label: objects
Entity-object.description: In this context, 'objects' refers to the fundamental components of various mathematical structures, such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, which are manipulated within a proposed formalism to influence the properties of the resulting combined structures.

Entity-product_of_them.label: products of them
Entity-product_of_them.description: The term 'products of them' refers to the mathematical combinations or constructs formed by the interaction and integration of various elementary structures such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs within the proposed formalism.

Entity-rewriting_system.label: rewriting systems
Entity-rewriting_system.description: Rewriting systems are formal systems used in computer science and mathematics to define the transformation of strings or structures through the application of rules, serving as a foundational concept in formal grammars and computational models.

Entity-tag.label: TAG
Entity-tag.description: TAG refers to Tree Adjoining Grammar, a formal grammar framework used in computational linguistics that allows for the representation of complex syntactic structures.

Entity-grammar_formalism.label: grammar formalisms
Entity-grammar_formalism.description: Grammar formalisms are structured systems or theories used to define and analyze the syntax and semantics of languages through formal rules and representations.

Entity-mathematical_formalism.label: mathematical formalism
Entity-mathematical_formalism.description: Mathematical formalism refers to a structured and systematic approach to representing and manipulating mathematical concepts and relationships using symbols and rules.

Entity-hpsg.label: HPSG
Entity-hpsg.description: HPSG, or Head-Driven Phrase Structure Grammar, is a formal grammar framework used in computational linguistics and natural language processing that emphasizes the role of heads in syntactic structures and integrates both syntactic and semantic information.

Entity-dependency_grammar.label: dependency grammars
Entity-dependency_grammar.description: Dependency grammars are a type of formal grammar that represent the syntactic structure of sentences through the relationships between words, focusing on the dependencies between them rather than hierarchical phrase structures.

Entity-lfg.label: LFG
Entity-lfg.description: LFG refers to Lexical Functional Grammar, a formal grammar framework used in linguistic theory to describe the syntax and semantics of natural languages.

Entity-dag.label: dags
Entity-dag.description: DAGs, or Directed Acyclic Graphs, are a type of data structure and mathematical object that consist of nodes connected by directed edges, where no cycles exist, allowing for a hierarchical representation of relationships.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, theories, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

summary: This paper proposes a generic mathematical formalism for the combination of various structures : strings , trees , dags , graphs , and products of them . The polarization of the objects of the elementary structures controls the saturation of the final structure . This formalism is both elementary and powerful enough to strongly simulate many grammar formalisms , such as rewriting systems , dependency grammars , TAG , HPSG and LFG .

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject puts forward an idea, suggestion, or plan for consideration or discussion, which is represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is actively advocating for the acceptance or exploration of the object.

Predicate-for_the_combination_of.label: for the combination of
Predicate-for_the_combination_of.description: The predicate 'for the combination of' indicates a purpose or function that connects the subject to the object by suggesting that the subject serves as a means or framework to facilitate the integration, unification, or synthesis of the elements represented by the object. It implies that the subject is designed or utilized to enable the merging or interaction of the various components denoted by the object.

Predicate-controls.label: controls
Predicate-controls.description: The predicate 'controls' indicates a relationship in which the subject exerts influence or authority over the object, determining or regulating its state, behavior, or characteristics. This connection implies that changes or conditions in the subject have a direct impact on the object, establishing a dynamic interaction where the subject governs the properties or outcomes associated with the object.

Predicate-strongly_simulates.label: strongly simulates
Predicate-strongly_simulates.description: The predicate 'strongly simulates' indicates a robust and effective representation or imitation of the characteristics, behaviors, or functionalities of the object by the subject. It suggests that the subject provides a high degree of fidelity in mimicking or replicating the essential aspects of the object, often in a way that is useful for analysis, understanding, or application.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' establishes a relationship where the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part of its broader category or framework. It indicates that the object is a subset, component, or specific instance that falls within the scope of the subject.

Predicate-simulates.label: simulates
Predicate-simulates.description: The predicate 'simulates' indicates that the subject is capable of representing, imitating, or reproducing the behavior, characteristics, or properties of the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject serves as a model or an approximation of the object, often used in contexts such as scientific, computational, or theoretical frameworks.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or making known the object to an audience. It implies a communicative act where the subject conveys information, findings, or concepts related to the object, often in a formal or structured manner.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset that falls under the wider category or concept represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a broader scope or definition that includes the subject within its framework.
